alert.note: Alert for Wayne (Missouri) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Paducah (Southern Illinois and Indiana, Southeastern Missouri and Western Kentucky)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued February 17 at 9:03AM CST until February 19 at 2:28AM CST by NWS Paducah
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Paducah KY has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Missouri... St. Francis River near Patterson affecting Wayne County. .High soil moisture along with significant rainfall and expected snowmelt upstream will cause sharp rises on the St. Francis River at Patterson this afternoon, bringing the river to minor flood stage later this afternoon. Depending on the volume of water running downstream through the St. Francis River, the river could approach moderate flood stage on Friday. Those persons living near the river should pay close attention to water levels and seek higher ground, if necessary. For the St. Francis River...including Patterson...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING THROUGH LATE FRIDAY NIGHT... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...St. Francis River near Patterson. * WHEN...From this evening to early Saturday morning. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 AM CST Thursday the stage was 8.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage this evening to a crest of 23.0 feet tomorrow morning. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow evening. - Flood stage is 16.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 22.6 feet on 05/31/1997. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Stay tuned to further developments by listening to your local radio, television, or NOAA Weather Radio for further information. Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
